caption: Figure 1: Long Narrative Video Generation. We curate a large-scale cooking video dataset to develop an interleaved auto-regressive model – VideoAuteur, which acts as a narrative director, sequentially generating actions, captions, and keyframes (two generated examples here). These elements condition a video generation model to create long narrative videos.
description: The figure showcases the VideoAuteur model, which generates long narrative videos by sequentially producing actions, captions, and keyframes.  A large-scale cooking video dataset was used to train this interleaved autoregressive model.  Two example videos are shown, illustrating the model's ability to create coherent and detailed long-form video content from text and image embeddings.

caption: Figure 2: CookGen contains long narrative videos annotated with actions and captions. Each source video is cut into clips and matched with the labeled “actions”. We use refined pseudo labels from ASR for Howto100M videos and use manual annotations for Youcook2 videos. We use state-of-the-art VLMs (i.e. GPT-4o and a finetuned video captioner) to provide high-quality captions for all video clips.
description: The figure displays example clips from the CookGen dataset.  CookGen is a dataset of long-form cooking videos, each broken down into short clips with corresponding actions and captions.  The actions were determined using a combination of automatic speech recognition (ASR) for HowTo100M videos and manual annotation for YouCook2 videos.  High-quality captions were generated for all clips using state-of-the-art Vision-Language Models (VLMs) like GPT-4.

caption: Figure 3: Long Narrative Video Director. The video director, a Visual Language Model (VLM), takes a user query (e.g., “How to cook a tuna sandwich?”) and an initial image-text pair as input. It then generates captions, actions, and visual states step-by-step. Each video clip is created using either visual embeddings or a keyframe derived from these embeddings. This study focuses on key design choices, such as the visual latent space, regression loss for visual embeddings, and the regression task.
description: The figure illustrates the Long Narrative Video Director, a Visual Language Model (VLM), which takes a user query (e.g., "How to cook a tuna sandwich?") and an initial image-text pair as input. It generates captions, actions, and visual states step-by-step, creating a sequence of video clips.  Each clip is generated using visual embeddings or a keyframe. The diagram highlights design decisions such as the visual latent space, regression loss for visual embeddings, and the regression task itself.

caption: Figure 4: Visual-Conditioned video generation. Our interleaved auto-regressive director generates both text and visual conditions, enabling the video generation process to be conditioned either on keyframes (VAE embeddings) or on CLIP latents regressed by the interleaved director. We apply Gaussain noise, random masking and random shuffling as regularization during the training process to improve robustness with the imperfect visual embeddings.
description: This figure illustrates the visual-conditioned video generation process, a key component of the proposed VideoAuteur framework.  The interleaved auto-regressive director plays a crucial role, generating both text captions and visual embeddings (which can represent either keyframes or CLIP latents). These outputs act as conditions for the video generation model, allowing the generation to be guided by either pre-computed visual representations (keyframes from a VAE) or learned visual features (regressed CLIP embeddings).  To enhance the model's robustness and handle noisy or imperfect visual embeddings produced by the director, Gaussian noise, random masking, and random shuffling are incorporated as regularization techniques during training.

caption: Figure 5: Auto-encoded results with different latent spaces. While SEED-X and EMU-2 both use a CLIP vision encoder and a diffusion model (i.e. finetuned SDXL) as decoder for autoencoding visual latents, SEED-X is semantic-biased and EMU-2 keeps much more visual details. SDXL-VAE shows the best image reconstruction ability, however, the latent space is not aligned with language (i.e. without pretraining on image-text pairs like CLIP).
description: This figure compares the autoencoding results using different latent spaces.  Three models, SEED-X, EMU-2, and SDXL-VAE, are used to encode and decode images.  SEED-X and EMU-2 leverage a CLIP vision encoder and a fine-tuned Stable Diffusion model (SDXL) as the decoder, while SDXL-VAE utilizes a variational autoencoder. SEED-X prioritizes semantic information, resulting in encoded representations that are heavily biased towards the meaning of the image.  EMU-2, on the other hand, preserves more visual details in its encoding.  SDXL-VAE achieves the best image reconstruction, however, its latent space lacks alignment with language because it was not pretrained on image-text pairs as CLIP models are.

caption: Figure 6: Both Scale and Direction Matters. We experiment with pseudo regression errors by altering latent direction and scale using Gaussian noise and scaling factors. The reconstruction results confirm that preserving both scale and direction is essential for accurate latent regression.
description: This figure shows an ablation study evaluating the impact of scale and direction on the accuracy of latent regression in a video generation model.  The model uses visual embeddings, and the experiment introduces controlled errors by either adding Gaussian noise (affecting direction) or scaling factors (affecting scale). The reconstruction quality is then measured for each variation to determine which aspects are most critical to preserving the quality of the video's visual representation. The results demonstrate that maintaining both the correct scale and direction of the visual embedding is essential for effective latent regression.

caption: Figure 7: Quality Comparison Example. Given a global system prompt—“Step-by-step guide to cooking mapo tofu:”—along with the action, caption, and image embeddings of the first step keyframe, our interleaved director sequentially generates ”actions,” ”captions,” and image embeddings to construct a narrative on how to cook the dish step by step. The first two rows display the directly generated keyframes (decoded from the image latents) using the EMU-2 and SEED-X latent spaces. The generated images are realistic with strong visual consistency but are less aesthetically refined than those produced by state-of-the-art text-to-image models, i.e. SDXL and FLUX.1-s.
description: This figure compares the image generation quality of different models given a cooking recipe prompt.  An interleaved autoregressive director generates a sequence of actions, captions, and visual embeddings to describe the cooking process step-by-step. These are then used to generate images. The first two rows show keyframes generated by EMU-2 and SEED-X. While realistic and consistent, the image quality is slightly less refined than state-of-the-art text-to-image models (SDXL and FLUX-1-s) shown in the bottom rows.

caption: Figure 12: Statistics on the video data. We do statistics on the video lengths of the collected whole videos, the clip lengths of the scene-cut video clips, and the number of clips selected for each video.

caption: Figure 13: Statistics on the text annotations. We do statistics on the number of words and tokens (Llama [46] tokenized) of annotated “actions” and “captions,” respectively.
description: This figure presents the statistical distribution of the word and token counts for both action and caption annotations within the CookGen dataset.  Histograms visualize the frequency distribution of the number of words and Llama tokens across various ranges, providing insights into the textual complexity and length variations in both action and caption annotations. This information helps in understanding the richness and descriptiveness of the dataset's textual components, essential for evaluating and benchmarking models trained on this data.

caption: Figure 14: Left: Ground truth, Right: Inverse generation with GT keyframe. Caption: Chunks of meat are simmering in a dark-colored slow cooker. description: The figure shows a comparison between a ground truth frame from a cooking video and a reconstructed frame generated using only the caption and ground truth keyframes. The ground truth image shows this process, while the reconstruction is close but reveals minor differences, highlighting the challenges of perfectly reconstructing visual details from captions alone.
